articles.headline: This Season’s Hottest Shopping Trend: Falling Prices
articles.snippet: As inflation slows, prices for some physical goods are falling outright, which could lift consumers’ spirits.
articles.abstract: As inflation slows, prices for some physical goods are falling outright, which could lift consumers’ spirits.
articles.lead_paragraph: American shoppers, burned by more than two years of rapid inflation, are getting some welcome relief this holiday season: Prices on many products are falling.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman, Jordyn Holman and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: American Dream Deferred: Why Housing Prices May Pose a Problem for Biden
articles.snippet: Buying a home is a less attainable goal for many young people, and rents are expensive. Could that dog Democrats in the 2024 election?
articles.abstract: Buying a home is a less attainable goal for many young people, and rents are expensive. Could that dog Democrats in the 2024 election?
articles.lead_paragraph: Cameron Ambrosy spent the first weekend of December going to 10 open houses — purely for research purposes. The 25-year-old in St. Paul, Minn., has a well-paying job and she and her husband are saving diligently, but she knows that it will be years before they can afford to buy.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Jim Tankersley and Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: Jury Orders Giuliani to Pay $148 Million to Election Workers He Defamed
articles.snippet: Ruby Freeman and Shaye Moss, wrongfully accused by Rudolph W. Giuliani of having tried to steal votes from Donald J. Trump in Georgia, were awarded the damages by a federal court in Washington.
articles.abstract: Ruby Freeman and Shaye Moss, wrongfully accused by Rudolph W. Giuliani of having tried to steal votes from Donald J. Trump in Georgia, were awarded the damages by a federal court in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: A jury on Friday ordered Rudolph W. Giuliani to pay $148 million to two former Georgia election workers who said he had destroyed their reputations with lies that they tried to steal the 2020 election from Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: A Viral Dance and ‘Happiness Campaign’ Frustrates Iran’s Clerics
articles.snippet: It all started when a 70-year-old fish market stall owner nicknamed “Booghy” was grooving in public, in violation of Iranian law.
articles.abstract: It all started when a 70-year-old fish market stall owner nicknamed “Booghy” was grooving in public, in violation of Iranian law.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new form of protest against the government is rocking Iran: a viral dance craze set to an upbeat folk song where crowds clap and chant the rhythmic chorus, “Oh, oh, oh, oh.”
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar

articles.headline: Israel Found the Hamas Money Machine Years Ago. Nobody Turned It Off.
articles.snippet: Agents worried as millions poured in. Hamas bought weapons and plotted an attack. The authorities now say the money helped lay the groundwork for the Oct. 7 assault on Israel.
articles.abstract: Agents worried as millions poured in. Hamas bought weapons and plotted an attack. The authorities now say the money helped lay the groundwork for the Oct. 7 assault on Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli security officials scored a major intelligence coup in 2018: secret documents that laid out, in intricate detail, what amounted to a private equity fund that Hamas used to finance its operations.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker and Justin Scheck

articles.headline: The Debt Problem Is Enormous. Experts Say the System for Fixing It Is Broken.
articles.snippet: Economists offer alternatives to financial safeguards created when the U.S. was the pre-eminent superpower and climate change wasn’t on the agenda.
articles.abstract: Economists offer alternatives to financial safeguards created when the U.S. was the pre-eminent superpower and climate change wasn’t on the agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Guzman was a college freshman at La Universidad Nacional de La Plata, Argentina, in 2001 when a debt crisis prompted default, riots and a devastating depression. A dazed middle class suffered ruin, as the International Monetary Fund insisted that the government make misery-inducing budget cuts in exchange for a bailout.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: Fewer Electric Vehicles Will Qualify for Federal Tax Credits in 2024
articles.snippet: Purchases of popular models like the Tesla Model 3 and the Ford Mustang Mach-E may no longer entitle buyers to tax savings because the cars do not meet tougher sourcing requirements.
articles.abstract: Purchases of popular models like the Tesla Model 3 and the Ford Mustang Mach-E may no longer entitle buyers to tax savings because the cars do not meet tougher sourcing requirements.
articles.lead_paragraph: Efforts to fight global warming could suffer a setback next year when new rules reduce the number of electric cars that qualify for a federal tax credit.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Israel Says 3 Hostages Bore White Flag Before Being Killed by Troops
articles.snippet: The military said the mistaken killing of the three men, who had been shirtless, was a violation of its rules of engagement.
articles.abstract: The military said the mistaken killing of the three men, who had been shirtless, was a violation of its rules of engagement.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Israeli military on Saturday said three hostages mistakenly killed by Israeli troops had been shirtless, unarmed and bearing a makeshift white flag. The troubling details of how they died have created widespread anguish and prompted renewed calls for a pause in the fighting to allow more hostages to be released.
articles.byline: By Aaron Boxerman, Ben Hubbard and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: How Putin Turned a Western Boycott Into a Bonanza
articles.snippet: If companies want to leave Russia, the president is setting the terms — in ways that benefit his government, his elites and his war.
articles.abstract: If companies want to leave Russia, the president is setting the terms — in ways that benefit his government, his elites and his war.
articles.lead_paragraph: If companies want to leave Russia, the president is setting the terms — in ways that benefit his government, his elites and his war.
articles.byline: By Paul Sonne, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Nico Chilla

articles.headline: 7 Months Inside an Online Scam Labor Camp
articles.snippet: A man was abducted by a Chinese gang and forced to work in a scam operation. He gathered financial information, photos and videos and shared the material with The New York Times.
articles.abstract: A man was abducted by a Chinese gang and forced to work in a scam operation. He gathered financial information, photos and videos and shared the material with The New York Times.
articles.lead_paragraph: A man was abducted by a Chinese gang and forced to work in a scam operation. He gathered financial information, photos and videos and shared the material with The New York Times.
articles.byline: By Isabelle Qian and Pablo Robles

articles.headline: Why Democracy Hasn’t Settled the Abortion Question
articles.snippet: Post-Roe voting might bring America to a new consensus — but only if the voters keep getting their say.
articles.abstract: Post-Roe voting might bring America to a new consensus — but only if the voters keep getting their say.
articles.lead_paragraph: As long as the Supreme Court’s decision in Roe v. Wade was the law of the land, conservatives complained that it had squelched the democratic process — that unelected men in black robes had handed down a national edict rather than letting the American people sort out a consensus.
articles.byline: By Kate Zernike

articles.headline: Did the Grinch Come for the Office Holiday Party?
articles.snippet: Hark, the herald angels shout: 9 p.m. is too late to be out.
articles.abstract: Hark, the herald angels shout: 9 p.m. is too late to be out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Much like skirt hemlines, which supposedly get shorter in boom times and lengthen when the economy teeters, office holiday parties have never been immune to the flux of the broader corporate world. Since remote work emptied out offices, and after years of holiday plans overturned by Covid, companies have been rethinking their festivities. For some, boozy nighttime parties are out; in their place are conference room lunches and mingling over mocktails.
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg

articles.headline: Campus Crackdowns Have Chilling Effect on Pro-Palestinian Speech
articles.snippet: Universities are under tremendous pressure to stamp out antisemitism, but some say that is causing fear and curbing free expression.
articles.abstract: Universities are under tremendous pressure to stamp out antisemitism, but some say that is causing fear and curbing free expression.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the University of Pennsylvania, approval for the screening of a documentary critical of Israel was denied.
articles.byline: By Vimal Patel and Anna Betts

articles.headline: More Than 100 Members of This Gaza Clan Have Been Killed in War
articles.snippet: Family trees have been dismembered, and whole branches obliterated, since the war between Israel and Hamas broke out on Oct. 7.
articles.abstract: Family trees have been dismembered, and whole branches obliterated, since the war between Israel and Hamas broke out on Oct. 7.
articles.lead_paragraph: People whispered that Nasser al-Astal had come undone, dazed by grief. Weeks after the Israeli airstrike that he said had crashed into his family’s home, his words came in loud, quivering spurts, darting frantically from memory to memory, from loss to loss — his wife, two of their sons and four of their daughters, all dead.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee and Iyad Abuheweila

articles.headline: Israel’s Allies Urge Restraint as Netanyahu Vows ‘Fight to the End’
articles.snippet: The U.S. defense secretary was headed to the Middle East as two top European officials called for a scaled-back war against Hamas.
articles.abstract: The U.S. defense secretary was headed to the Middle East as two top European officials called for a scaled-back war against Hamas.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Israeli military bombarded dozens of sites in the Gaza Strip over the weekend as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed to keep fighting in the territory, even as anguish over the Israeli military’s accidental killings of three hostages raised new questions about how his government is prosecuting the war.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams, Adam Sella and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Wall Street’s ‘Bond Vigilantes’ Are at Battle as U.S. Debt Soars
articles.snippet: The financial world has been debating if market appetite for U.S. debt is near a limit. Not everyone agrees this is something to panic about, but the ramifications for funding government priorities are immense.
articles.abstract: The financial world has been debating if market appetite for U.S. debt is near a limit. Not everyone agrees this is something to panic about, but the ramifications for funding government priorities are immense.
articles.lead_paragraph: Typically, the esoteric inner workings of finance and the very public stakes of government spending are viewed as separate spheres.
articles.byline: By Talmon Joseph Smith

articles.headline: E.V. Start-Up Founders Made Big Claims. One Was Just Sentenced to Prison.
articles.snippet: Trevor Milton, who founded the truck company Nikola, was sentenced on Monday in a fraud case that exposed the excesses in the electric vehicle business.
articles.abstract: Trevor Milton, who founded the truck company Nikola, was sentenced on Monday in a fraud case that exposed the excesses in the electric vehicle business.
articles.lead_paragraph: The founder of the electric truck company Nikola was sentenced to four years in prison on Monday in a fraud case that highlights the financial carnage left behind by a crop of electric vehicle start-ups and their promoters.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: U.S. Fines Southwest Airlines $140 Million for Holiday Meltdown
articles.snippet: The penalty is by far the largest ever imposed by the Transportation Department on an airline for consumer protection violations.
articles.abstract: The penalty is by far the largest ever imposed by the Transportation Department on an airline for consumer protection violations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department on Monday announced a $140 million fine against Southwest Airlines over a meltdown last winter that disrupted travel for about two million people during the holiday season.
articles.byline: By Mark Walker and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: Illicit Content on Elon Musk’s X Draws E.U. Investigation
articles.snippet: The inquiry is perhaps the most substantial regulatory move to date against X, which has seen a rise in incendiary content on the platform, according to researchers.
articles.abstract: The inquiry is perhaps the most substantial regulatory move to date against X, which has seen a rise in incendiary content on the platform, according to researchers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Union announced a formal investigation Monday into X, the social media platform owned by Elon Musk, accusing it of failing to counter illicit content and disinformation, a lack of transparency about advertising and “deceptive” design practices.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano

articles.headline: Pope Francis Allows Priests to Bless Same-Sex Couples
articles.snippet: A church official said the blessings amounted to “a real development” that nevertheless did not amend “the traditional doctrine of the church about marriage.”
articles.abstract: A church official said the blessings amounted to “a real development” that nevertheless did not amend “the traditional doctrine of the church about marriage.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The Vatican said Monday that Pope Francis had allowed priests to bless same-sex couples, his most definitive step yet to make the Roman Catholic Church more welcoming to L.G.B.T.Q. Catholics and more reflective of his vision of a more pastoral, and less rigid, church.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz
